instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2936: What is 820-2936? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCCSA_S0_CPU: What is PPVCCSA_S0_CPU? Main power rail for the CPU. If this is missing the machine will act braindead. This is NOT shorted to ground if it has a low resistance â€“ this is a common mistake people make. A chip that requires high power at a low voltage like a CPU or GPU will have a low measured resistance to ground..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
This board power and has all rails except CPU core. On <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> pin 1 is 0V

I lift <RESISTOR>R7974</RESISTOR> and on both pins still 0V

Board has stable 3.3V, 1.5V, 12,57V, 1,05V, 1.8V.
No liquide damage. Customer told that happend when connect sound card throught the USB.

----------------------------------
L7100 - also missing 0V; 25ohm to ground; Diode mode 0.03
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL> - 3.3V
<SIGNAL>PVCCSA_EN</SIGNAL> - 3.2V
<CHIP>U7100</CHIP> vcc and vpcc - 5V

First I have to solve missing L7100 and then CPU core, right?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
Usually when <SIGNAL>PPVCCSA_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> is missing you don't get fan spin or <SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>.

I'd start with replacing <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
Macbook comes again.

This time I replaced 

<CHIP>U7100</CHIP>
<CHIP>U7300</CHIP>

both chips are bad.

and works ok. 
Customer told me this happend when connecting sound card throught the usb port and in several seconds macbook die.
Any idea what could be that problem? Customer use china ac adapter.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message:
Anything can happen with those chargers, I've seen bad USB devices kill random ICs or causing board issues before as well though, so it could be....
If it works now I'd say its resolved, but definitely get the customer to stop using the shitty charger!

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2936</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> missing cpu core
threads.message: And it will come again if they keep using $5 China chargers.
